title: What will the end-of-day YTD return be for the Bloomberg Barclays US Aggregate Bond Index on 29 December, 2017?
preds: Shifting to 100 because there's only a few weeks left in the year and the return is currently 3.56%.
the return profile has trended sideways since late October - with last few weeks of the year remaining, little catalyst on why this would not continue
a couple of weeks left of liquidity. Expect little volatility into year end with most central bank events out of the way.
By my calculations the index needs to close above 2,025 to reach +2.5% return. It hasn’t been below that point since July 25th.
Shifting higher in line with the current YTD return and the one year return.
Current YTD return is 3.32%.  Over the last 5 years, the index has not gained or lost more than 5bps in the month of December.
The bond market has taken notice of likely deficits.

Significantly increasing the likelihood of a return of less than -2.5% to 2.5% on reports that Trump may be inclined to name John Taylor as the next Fed chair on Nov. 3.  If that happens, and I believe it fits Trump's modus operandi, the markets may quickly discount the likelihood of several sharp increases the in Fed funds rates.  The "Taylor Rule" would have rates 180 basis points higher than now.  If the 10-year were to increase by a mere 25 to 50 basis points, that would put the return on the index at 1% to 2.2%, and at -5.1% if it were to fully discount the difference to get to John Taylor's target of 3.0%.   Consider that rates have jumped 6.7 basis points in just two days on speculation about a "Taylor Tantrum", causing the return to change by -14 bps. and you can  see that forecasting participants are probably underestimating this risk for this question.

Based on a duration of 6, a move in rates of 25 basis points in either direction would put the total return of AGG out of the 2.5% to 5.0% range.  This 25 bps is not a great move, and could easily happen in nine weeks, so assigning 90% to the 2.5%-5.0% range seems risky.  But I don't think that such a move will occur more than 1/3 of the time, so anything less than 70% seems risky, too.  The yield on the 10-year Treasury has been oddly stable this year, so that has to be taken into account as well, as market participants seem to be signaling intransigence.  77% seems like a  reasonable estimate.
YTD return is on a 3 handle, and simple interest accrual will bump it up toward 5% by year-end, assuming prices and yields don't change-   but to me the bond market looks poised for a sell off.

The yield curve appears to be flattening, and the recent backup in the 10-year yield appears to be peaking, and could slide back toward the 2% level by year end, which would support higher AGG returns.
Currently 3.2 and movement is minuscule. I say 3.4, still some growth opportunity.
there is an increased probability of the 0% to < 2.5% band, as rates have been ticking higher. A year-end 10yr bond yield of approx. 2.5% or greater would do the trick.......just saying.

in 2016 the return was more or less 5% after a drop we have seen a strong recover in 2017. It will be in the same range eventually a little bit higher then one year before. The question is if the index will drop before Christmas, or in the new year.
Based on standard deviation of around 3.0 for returns
Already at 3.4% YTD. Looking at continued increases in the federal rate, both with fed drawing down QED reserves and likely raising interest rates in December.
Still looking for a selloff in Q4 in reaction to Fed balance sheet trimming plus tax reform (increased deficits, higher growth)
3.15% on 22 Sept. Headed down. It has dropped 11% in 4.5 weeks since 29 August. 14 more weeks to go.
Currently 3.28, maybe more volatile than I thought

Inflation has been quietly firming, and some of the supply shocks (e.g., reduced refining capacity) and logistical friction from recent hurricanes could lead to inflation surprises in the months to come.  This, plus the solid cyclical backdrop, will likely prompt the Fed to resume rate hikes in December.
Currently 3.92, rising rapidly at present. Flight to bonds? why?
Currently 3.92, rising rapidly at present. Flight to bonds? why? Rebalancing of portfolios away from stocks?
Returns are shifting up and so am I.

Marking the passage of time on my largely correct forecast that rates would remain subdued just eight years post the global financial crisis.  Fed is still worried about inflation being too low.  Cruise control.

Explanation of what's in it: "The Bloomberg Barclays US Aggregate Bond Index is a broad-based flagship benchmark that measures the investment grade, US dollar-denominated, fixed-rate taxable bond market. The index includes Treasuries, government-related and corporate  securities,  MBS  (agency  fixed-rate  and  hybrid  ARM  pass-throughs),  ABS  and  CMBS  (agency  and  non-agency)." More information: https://www.bbhub.io/indices/sites/2/2016/08/2017-02-08-Factsheet-US-Aggregate.pdf It increased from 2.71 on July 31 to 3.49 on August 29.
Shifting ten points higher to account for the YTD return being over 2.5 and the fact that its August.

I'm tightening my ranges to account for the diminishing time left for this question. With bond market interest income  for the next 4.5 months, the return would come in at 3.7%, about the midpoint between 2.5% and 5%.  A 25 basis-point parallel shift in either direction across the yield curve would push the total return to just outside that range, so there's some cushion.  Importantly, Fed rate increases during 2017 have had minimal effect on longer rates: mostly downward, as is typical historically during periods of Fed rate hikes.  The 10-year yield has been remarkably stable this year.
Currently 3.14, seems to be stable markets at present
What a difference a few days of brinksmanship makes. The 1-year return has surged to 0.20%, while the YTD return has topped 3% (3.06%).
I think within this range most likely seems to be the scenario.
2.6% influx of investments outside of oil production.

YTW is 2,61 for the index, reutrn YTD is 2,96%, so my base case scenario is a 3,80YTD for the year. Then I´ve used projections of bollinger bands for standard deviations and gave more weight to the downside than to the upside as my personal belief is that current bond valuations are not sustainable over time. All data used was taken from Bloomberg. https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/LBUSTRUU:IND

YTW is 2,61 for the index, reutrn YTD is 3,09%, so my base case scenario is a 3,96YTD for the year. Then I´ve used projections of bollinger bands for standard deviations and gave more weight to the downside than to the upside as my personal belief is that current bond valuations are not sustainable over time. All data used was taken from Bloomberg.
YTD is currently 2.36% with half the year left to go.
the year is halfway over and it seems to be going up at 2.2 percent per 7 months

Two successful hedge fund managers who have connections that individual investors only dream of are on opposite sides of where rates are headed (Ray Dalio down and David Tepper up). Very convincing arguments by both.  Approaching May highs  $2.42 and strong resistance at $2.65. When central bankers talk higher rates the stock market starts to tank and they send someone out to walk back comments. Debt (corporate, public and private) is at levels that are unsustainable at higher levels, per smarter people then me. It appears central banks are preparing for a recession or are trying to pop asset prices. Rasing 3rd category by 5% and lowering 4th by that amount.

As of this forecast, the 1-yr return was -1.48%, while the YTD return was 1.90%. The Federal Reserve has announced it course of action, but could be upended by inaction on Capitol Hill or events abroad. I'm thus putting down an uncertainty marker, which will be subject to regular review.
December is a long way off. But, I'm adjusting my expectations here.

YTW is 2,61 for the index, YTD 2% so far, so my base case scenario is a 3,25YTD by 29 december. Then I´ve used projections of bollinger bands for standard deviations and gave more weight to the downside than to the upside as my personal belief is that current bond valuations are not sustainable over time. All data used was taken from Bloomberg.
The year started with a drop, and sale of the govt troubled asset bond holdings begins this year

I think the economy is weaker then the Fed is saying it is. Employment may be up but wages are still suppressed so unless their intention is to burst the stock market,  category two is most likely with a slight chance it makes it into category 3 on the Fed preparing for the next recession.
The more I read the more I think the between 2.5 and 3.5 is where this will be.

So the performance of this index has fluctuated quite a bit in the last few years (see link) and that makes forecasting a little annoying. That said, the YTD return is around 2.5% so I think that's a good place to start. I'm going to keep monitoring this question but right now I'm falling evenly around 2.5%. http://performance.morningstar.com/Performance/index-c/performance-return.action?t=XIUSA000MC

There is one more FED hike penciled in for 2017 and with that a general improvement in the return from fixed income assets, which should drive a stronger demand. This will also enable a hedging against possible risks in the US equity market, which a number of top investment banks are warning against. On the other hand, the FED balance sheet reduction will increase the supply of bonds (mainly treasuries) which could suppress returns. Whether this will have much of an effect by the end of the year remains to be seen.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-11/wall-street-again-slashes-2017-yield-forecasts-ahead-of-fed-hike
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-07/bill-gross-says-market-risk-is-highest-since-before-2008-crisis
Investors have deluded themselves so far this administration...
Lately anybody who think they know what the bond market will do isn't paying attention.  Stay tuned.
